reasoning: This targets a load-bearing assumption in the paper: representing moral views with a single vNM-style cardinal value function and using that to define ‘mostly-great’/‘eutopia’ thresholds and “narrow target” claims. If the fussiness result fails under plausible non-vNM moral/decision frameworks (incomparability, lexicality, deontic constraints, non-EUT choice rules), the paper’s central generality claim could be substantially weakened, potentially shifting emphasis back toward survival-only work or changing what “steering to eutopia” even means. It’s quite paper-specific (wouldn’t arise the same way without this paper’s fussy/easygoing framework), and fairly clear, but it bundles several distinct relaxations (each could behave differently), which slightly reduces clarity and makes the research program broader. It is moderately tractable via formal analysis (e.g., imprecise/lexicographic utility models, choice under moral uncertainty, partial orderings) and by testing whether analogous ‘target narrowness’ notions can be defined, though it remains substantially philosophical. The strategic implications are gestured at (undermining generality) but not cleanly framed as alternative action recommendations under different possible answers.
title: Fussiness robustness beyond expected utility frameworks
